Clean and prepare excerpt-level coding data

Source: R/clean_data.R
clean_data.Rd

This function cleans a dataset of coded excerpts exported from Dedoose (or a similar qualitative coding platform). It standardizes variable names, converts code columns to logicals, filters to the preferred coder per transcript, and assigns variable labels. A codebook is also generated and saved to the global environment.

Usage

clean_data(excerpts, preferred_coders)

Arguments

excerpts

A data frame containing raw excerpt-level coding data. Must include at least the columns media_title and excerpt_creator.

preferred_coders

A character vector of coder IDs in order of preference (e.g., c("a", "l", "i", "r")).

Value

A cleaned data frame of excerpts with standardized columns, filtered to the preferred coder, and with labeled variables. A codebook data frame is also assigned to the global environment.

Details

The cleaning steps performed are:

  1. Standardize all column names to lowercase and replace spaces with underscores.

  2. Rename excerpt_copy to excerpt if present.

  3. Drop columns ending in "range" or "weight".

  4. Identify code columns (names starting with "code" and ending with "applied").

  5. Convert code columns from text to logical (TRUE if "true", otherwise FALSE).

  6. Clean and rename code column names by stripping prefixes/suffixes and adding a c_ prefix.

  7. Save the final set of cleaned code column names for labeling.

  8. Filter to the preferred coder for each media_title, based on the order of preferred_coders.

  9. Apply human-readable variable labels for common metadata fields and all code columns.

  10. Generate a codebook (variable, label, and type) and assign it to the global environment as codebook.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Example usage
raw_excerpts <- readxl::read_xlsx("inst/raw_data/test_data.xlsx")
preferred <- c("a", "l", "i", "r", "s")
cleaned <- clean_data(raw_excerpts, preferred)

# View the automatically created codebook
head(codebook)
} # }
